{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Italic title}} {{lang|fr|'''"Vive le Québec libre !'''"}} ({{IPA-fr|vivᵊ ləkebɛk ˈlibʁᵊ|lang}}, "Long live free Quebec!") was a controversial phrase in a speech delivered by [[Charles de Gaulle|President Charles de Gaulle]] of France on July 24, 1967, during an official visit to Canada under the pretext of attending [[Expo 67]] in Montreal, Quebec. While giving an address to a large crowd from a balcony at [[Montreal City Hall]], he uttered {{lang|fr|"Vive Montréal ! Vive le Québec !"}} ("Long live Montreal, Long live Quebec!") and then added, followed by loud applause, {{lang|fr|"Vive le Québec {{noitalic|libre}} !"}} ("Long live ''free'' Quebec!") with particular emphasis on the word {{lang|fr|"libre"}}. The phrase, a slogan used by Quebecers who favoured [[Quebec sovereignty movement|Quebec sovereignty]], and de Gaulle's use of it was seen by them as giving his support to the movement. The speech sparked a diplomatic incident with Canada's government, and was condemned by [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Lester B. Pearson]], saying that "Canadians do not need to be liberated".<ref>{{cite web|title=Prime Minister Pearson stands up to de Gaulle|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/prime-ministers/lester-b-pearson-from-peacemaker-to-prime-minister/standing-up-to-de-gaulle.html|website=CBC Digital Archives|accessdate=December 20, 2014}}</ref> In France, though many were sympathetic to the cause of Quebec nationalism, de Gaulle's speech was criticized as a breach of protocol.
==Background== [[File:Charles de Gaulle-1963.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|Charles de Gaulle in 1963]] Even before his arrival, the [[Government of Canada|Canadian federal government]] had been concerned about President de Gaulle's visit. Earlier that year, the French government had not sent a high-level representative to the funeral service for [[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[Georges Vanier]].<ref name="Thomson 1988pp188-9">{{harvnb|Thomson|1988|pp=188–189}}</ref> This attracted notice in Canada, as Vanier and his wife, [[Pauline Vanier|Pauline]], had been personal friends of de Gaulle since 1940, when the latter was in exile in [[London, England]].<ref name="Thomson 1988pp188-9"/> In April, de Gaulle did not attend the 50th anniversary ceremonies commemorating the Canadian victory at [[Vimy Ridge]].<ref name="Vimy Ridge 1967">{{cite news | last = Harvey | first = Allen | title = Phillip amoung {{sic|nolink=y}} 15,000 at Vimy but not Charles De Gaulle | newspaper = The Globe and Mail | date = April 10, 1967 | location = Toronto | pages = 1, 17}} </ref> So worried was the Pearson government about potential interference of France in domestic affairs that [[Secretary of State for External Affairs (Canada)|Secretary of State for External Affairs]], [[Paul Joseph James Martin|Paul Martin]], was dispatched to visit de Gaulle in Paris to mend the two countries' relationship. The ''[[Montreal Gazette]]'' speculated, 45 years after the incident, that de Gaulle was still annoyed over a perceived slight from World War II-era Canadian Prime Minister [[William Lyon Mackenzie King|Mackenzie King]]'s slow recognition of the new French government in late summer 1944.<ref name="DeGaulle's Speech 45-years later">{{cite news |last = Kalbfleisch |first = John |title = Second Draft: De Gaulle’s Montreal speeches a study in contrast |url = https://montrealgazette.com/news/Second+Draft+Gaulle+Montreal+speeches+study+contrast/6930795/story.html#ixzz21b8YZtyB |accessdate = July 24, 2012 |newspaper = The Gazette |date = July 13, 2012 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/69PUeHS6Z?url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Second%20Draft%20Gaulle%20Montreal%20speeches%20study%20contrast/6930795/story.html |archivedate = July 25, 2012 |location = Montreal |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }} </ref>
In the spring of 1966, as part of the Expo 67 diplomatic protocols, de Gaulle and all world leaders whose countries had an exhibit at the fair were invited to visit Canada during the spring and summer of 1967.<ref name="Berton 302-303">{{harvnb|Berton|1967|pp=302–303}}</ref> A few months later, de Gaulle was also sent a separate invitation to visit Quebec by [[Premier of Quebec|Quebec premier]] [[Daniel Johnson, Sr.|Daniel Johnson]].<ref name="Berton 302-303"/> Although a visiting head of state, the president did not arrive in the Canadian capital, [[Ottawa]], as would be conventional protocol. Instead, he took the time to sail on the French navy's Mediterranean flagship, the cruiser ''[[French cruiser Colbert (C611)|Colbert]]'', so that he could arrive in [[Quebec City]], the capital city of the province of Quebec.<ref name= "Berton (1997)">{{harvnb|Berton|1997|pp=300–312}}</ref> There, de Gaulle was cheered enthusiastically, while the new governor general, [[Roland Michener]], was booed by the same crowd when "[[God Save the Queen]]" was played at his arrival.<ref name="De Gaulle lands"> {{cite news | title = Quebec Gives De Gaulle, Warm Reserved Welcome | newspaper = The Globe and Mail | date = July 24, 1967 | author = Quebec Bureau | location = Toronto | pages = 1, 10}} </ref> In his speech, de Gaulle spoke of his country’s "evolving" ties with Quebec, hinting at his support for Quebec sovereignty.<ref name="Quebec City speech"> {{cite news | last = MacKenzie | first = Robert | title = De Gaulle Boosts 'Quebec-First' Mood | newspaper = The Toronto Daily Star | date = July 24, 1967 | page = 4 | edition = All-Star}}</ref>
==Speech== [[File:Montreal-Canada5884.JPG|thumb|upright=0.7|[[Montreal City Hall]]'s balcony where De Gaulle gave his speech.]] On July 15, before boarding the ''Colbert'', de Gaulle told Xavier Deniau: "They will hear me over there, it will make waves!"<ref name="Thomson 1988" /> He also confided to his son-in-law General [[Alain de Boissieu]] that: "I am going to strike a strong blow. Things are going to get hot. But it is necessary. It is the last chance to rectify the cowardice of France."<ref name="Thomson 1988" /> De Gaulle was referring to what he viewed as France's abandonment of 70,000 French colonists to the British after France was defeated in [[French and Indian War|the North American theatre]] of the [[Seven Years' War]] in 1763.
On July 24, de Gaulle arrived in Montreal and was driven up the ''[[Chemin du Roy]]'' to [[Montreal City Hall]], where Mayor [[Jean Drapeau]] and Premier Johnson waited. De Gaulle was not scheduled to speak that evening, but the crowd chanted for him; he told Drapeau: "I have to speak to those people who are calling for me". According to a number of personal interviews with high-ranking French officials, as well as documents he uncovered, scholar [[Dale C. Thomson]] wrote that de Gaulle's statement was planned, and that he used it when the opportunity presented itself.<ref name = "Thomson 1988">{{harvnb|Thomson|1988|p=199}}</ref>
De Gaulle stepped out onto the balcony to give a short address to the assembled masses which was also broadcast live on radio. In his speech he commented that his drive down the banks of the [[Saint Lawrence River]], lined as it had been with cheering crowds, reminded him of his triumphant return to Paris after the [[Liberation of Paris|liberation]] from Nazi Germany. The speech appeared to conclude with the words {{lang|fr|"Vive Montréal ! Vive le Québec !"}} ("Long live Montreal! Long live Quebec!"), but he then added, {{lang|fr|"Vive le Québec libre ! Vive, vive, vive le Canada français ! Et vive la France !"}} ("Long live free Quebec! Long live, long live, long live French Canada! And long live France!"),<ref name=cbc>{{cite news |last = Depoe |first = Norman |title = 'Vive le Québec libre!' |work = Newsmagazine |department = On This Day |publisher = CBC News |date = July 24, 1967 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/language-culture/language-culture-general/vive-le-quebec-libre.html |accessdate = July 24, 2012 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/69Oj6PyT2?url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/language-culture/language-culture-general/vive-le-quebec-libre.html |archivedate = July 24, 2012 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }} </ref> whereupon the crowd roared with approval, especially after hearing, {{lang|fr|"Vive le Québec libre!"}}. De Gaulle particularly emphasized the use of the word {{lang|fr|"libre"}}, as he leaned into the microphones and enunciated it more slowly and loudly than other elements of his speech.
==Reaction== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:General Charles De Gaulle at Expo 67 e000996503.jpg|thumb|A day after his "''Vive le Québec Libre!''" speech, Charles De Gaulle attracts a crowd at Montreal's [[Expo 67]] on July 25, 1967.]] --> This statement, coming from the French head of state, was considered a serious breach of [[diplomatic protocol]].<ref name="DeGaulle Flies Home">{{cite news | last = Gray | first = Walter | title = Pearson Rebukes Him—Now ... De Gaulle Going Home | newspaper = The Toronto Daily Star | date = July 26, 1967 | pages = 1–2 | quote = 3-Star Edition}} </ref><ref name="40-years later CBC">{{cite news |author = Canadian Press |title = 'Vive le Québec' libre Thrust Quebec onto International Stage |publisher = CBC News |date = July 24, 2007 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2007/07/24/qc-vivelequebeclibrea.html |accessdate = July 25, 2012 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/69Q7EpFsF?url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/story/2007/07/24/qc-vivelequebeclibrea.html |archivedate = July 25, 2012 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }} </ref> It emboldened the Quebec sovereignty movement, and produced tensions between the leadership of the two countries.<ref name = "40-years later CBC"/> The crowd's reaction to De Gaulle's phrase was emotional, and has been described as frenzied,<ref name = ce/> but it sparked controversy with English Canadians, as many were outraged at the implied threat to Canada's [[territorial integrity]].<ref name="DeGaulle Flies Home" /> [[Prime Minister of Canada|Canadian Prime Minister]] [[Lester B. Pearson]] rebuked de Gaulle with an official statement, delivered to the French Embassy on July 25, and read on national television that evening.<ref name="Pearson rebukes De Gaulle">{{cite news | last = Gillan | first = Michael | title = Words Unacceptable to Canadians: De Gaulle Rebuked by Pearson | newspaper = The Globe and Mail | date = July 26, 1967 | location = Toronto | pages = 1, 4}} </ref> He said "The people of Canada are free. Every province in Canada is free. Canadians do not need to be liberated. Indeed, many thousands of Canadians gave their lives in two world wars in the liberation of France and other European countries."<ref name="Pearson rebukes De Gaulle"/>
A media and diplomatic uproar ensued thereafter, which resulted in de Gaulle cutting short his visit to Canada.<ref name=ce>{{cite web |title = De Gaulle and 'Vive le Québec Libre' |work = The Canadian Encyclopedia |year = 2012 |url = http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/en/article/de-gaulle-and-vive-le-quebec-libre-feature/ |accessdate = July 24, 2012 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/69PPnq4FN?url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/PrinterFriendly.cfm?Params=A1ARTFET_E53 |archivedate = July 25, 2012 |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }} </ref> The day after the speech, de Gaulle visited Expo 67 and hosted a banquet at the French pavilion. On July 26, instead of continuing his visit on to Ottawa, where he was scheduled to meet with Prime Minister Pearson, he decided to return to France on a French military jet.<ref name = "Busby 2008">{{harvnb|Busby|2008|p=159}}</ref><ref name="Expo and departure">{{cite news |last= Gorrell |first= David |title= Ceremony at Airport Brief but Correct |newspaper= The Globe and Mail |date= July 27, 1967 |location= Toronto |page= 1}}</ref>
The newly appointed Canadian minister of justice, [[Pierre Trudeau]] publicly wondered what the French reaction would have been if a Canadian Prime Minister shouted, "[[Brittany]] to the [[Breton people|Bretons]]".<ref name = ce/> From then on, de Gaulle remained unimpressed by Trudeau, saying {{lang|fr|"Nous n'avons aucune concession, ni même aucune amabilité, à faire à M. Trudeau, qui est l'adversaire de la chose française au Canada."}} ("We have not one concession, nor even any courtesy, to extend to Mr. Trudeau, who is the enemy of the 'French fact' in Canada.")<ref name=vigile>{{cite web |last = Chartier |first = Jean |title = De Gaulle s'était adressé aux Québécois dès 1940 |publisher = vigile.net |date = July 23, 1997 |url = http://archives.vigile.net/ds-degaulle/docs/chartier-1940.html |accessdate = July 24, 2012 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/69PPYaLOf?url=http://archives.vigile.net/ds-degaulle/docs/chartier-1940.html |archivedate = July 25, 2012 |quote = Note that the phrase "''la chose française''" is incapable of direct translation into English. |deadurl = yes |df = mdy-all }} </ref> De Gaulle was also heavily criticized by a large part of the French media for his breach of international protocol, in particular by ''[[Le Monde]]''.<ref name="French Media Reaction">{{cite news | last = Spicer | first = Keith | title = Paris Perplexed by De Gaulle's Quebec Conduct | newspaper = The Globe and Mail | date = July 27, 1967 | location = Toronto | page = 23}} </ref>
Meanwhile, to members of the Quebec sovereignty movement, the speech was viewed as a watershed moment.<ref name = "40-years later CBC"/> Occurring soon after the [[Quiet Revolution]], and taking into account the low economic and political state of [[French Canadian]]s at the time, the support of a foreign head of state seemed to add credibility to the movement in the eyes of many, including future Quebec premier [[René Lévesque]].<ref name="Levesque on Brinkmanship">{{cite news | last = Block | first = Irwin | title = De Gaulle's Speech Masterly Mrinkmanship, Says Levesque | newspaper = The Toronto Daily Star | date = July 24, 1967 | page = 4 | quote = All-Star Edition}} </ref><ref name="10-years later, Lévesque">{{cite news | title = Levesque Pays Tribute to Charles de Gaulle | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=d1RVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gT4NAAAAIBAJ&dq=charles%20de%20gaulle%20vive%20le%20quebec%20libre%20speech%201967&pg=3782%2C11903 | accessdate = July 25, 2012 | newspaper = The Leader-Post | date = November 1, 1977 | agency = Reuters | location = Regina, Saskatchewan | page = 2}} </ref>
On the flight home from Montreal, de Gaulle told René de Saint-Légier de la Saussaye—his diplomatic counsellor—that the event was "a historical phenomenon that was perhaps foreseeable but it took a form that only the situation itself could determine. Of course, like many others I could have got away with a few polite remarks or diplomatic acrobatics, but when one is General De Gaulle, one does not have recourse to such expedients. What I did, I had to do it."<ref name="Thomson 1988 p243">{{harvnb|Thomson|1988|p=243}}</ref>
In 1969, de Gaulle visited [[Brittany]], during which, in [[Quimper]], he declaimed a poem written by his uncle (also called [[Charles de Gaulle (poet)|Charles de Gaulle]]) in the [[Breton language]], expressing devotion to Breton culture. The speech, well received by the crowd, followed a series of crackdowns on [[Breton nationalism]]. He was accused of double standards for, on the one hand demanding a "free" Quebec because of its linguistic differences from English-speaking Canada, while on the other oppressing the movement in Brittany.<ref name = "Ellis 1993">{{harvnb|Ellis|1993|p=62}}</ref> During this Quimper speech, he replied to this criticism that Brittany was free and had been freed by Bretons and other French forces during the Liberation, reminding that the [[French Resistance|Resistance]] was more intense in Brittany than in any other part of France, and that many Bretons had joined the [[Free French Forces]].<ref>{{cite web |first= Charles |last= de Gaulle |url= http://www.ina.fr/politique/presidents-de-la-republique/video/CAF88035484/allocution-du-general-de-gaulle-a-quimper.fr.html |via= French National Audiovisual Institute (INA) |title= Allocution du Général de Gaulle à Quimper |trans-title= Speech of General de Gaulle in Quimper |language= fr}}</ref>
